title: Right and Left React to Senator Bob Corker’s Rebuke of Trump
text:
Advertisement
Supported by
Right and Left React to Senator Bob Corker’s Rebuke of Trump
The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. That’s why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.
Has this series exposed you to new ideas? Tell us how. Email us at ourpicks@nytimes.com .
For an archive of all the Partisan Writing Roundups, check out Our Picks .
From the Right
Image
Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee in September.CreditAl Drago for The New York Times
“He has calibrated his retirement announcement to encourage speculation about a 2020 bid, for which his recent comments are clearly useful in positioning him as an establishment primary challenge to Trump. What is it, exactly, that anyone should respect here?”
_____
“If only a tiny bit of Corker’s independence and candor could be transferred to his party, we firmly believe the G.O.P., the Senate and the country would be infinitely better off. Other Republicans should take notice.”
_____
“That Corker is the only Republican openly remarking on the irresponsibility of this behavior is, frankly, an indictment of the rest of the party.”
_____
“Corker is saying out loud what I hear privately from sources throughout the military and the U.S. government, and from both foreign ambassadors and visiting foreign diplomats.”
_____
“Talk is better than nothing, but action is what counts.”
_____
“Take the Corker attack as yet another example of Trump’s lack of strategic vision.”
_____
_____
Have thoughts about this collection? Email feedback to ourpicks@nytimes.com .
Related Coverage
quotes: He has calibrated his retirement announcement to encourage speculation about a 2020 bid, for which his recent comments are clearly useful in positioning him as an establishment primary challenge to Trump.
What is it, exactly, that anyone should respect here?
If only a tiny bit of Corker’s independence and candor could be transferred to his party, we firmly believe the G.O.P., the Senate and the country would be infinitely better off.
That Corker is the only Republican openly remarking on the irresponsibility of this behavior is, frankly, an indictment of the rest of the party.
Corker is saying out loud what I hear privately from sources throughout the military and the U.S. government, and from both foreign ambassadors and visiting foreign diplomats.
Talk is better than nothing, but action is what counts.
Take the Corker attack as yet another example of Trump’s lack of strategic vision.
